profileText: A Representative from Maine; born in Henniker, Merrimack County, N.H., on April 19, 1800; moved with his parents to Brownfield, Maine, in 1802; attended the common schools at that place and at Sanford in 1815 and 1816; studied medicine; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1822 and commenced practice in Wilton, Maine; county attorney 1828-1834; moved to Farmington, Maine, in 1832 and continued the practice of law; elected as a Whig to the Thirty-second Congress (March 4, 1851-March 3, 1853); unsuccessful candidate for renomination; appointed State bank commissioner in 1857; county treasurer of Franklin County 1866-1868; again county attorney in 1869 and 1870; treasurer of the Franklin County Savings Bank 1868-1874; died in Farmington, May 15, 1874; interment in Riverside Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1759-1863, approximately 300 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers chiefly contain correspondence between Robert Goodenow and his family, especially during his term (1851-53) as U.S. representative in Washington, legal and political papers, and the journal of his grandfather, William Tyler, of a cruise to Québec during the French and Indian Wars, 1759-63. Members of the family represented include Goodenow's wife, Mary Goodenow, his brothers, Daniel Goodenow and William Goodenow, and his sister, Valeria (Goodenow) Stone.
